title: Conservation of energy - fall vs slide

content.description: Two blocks, Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> are both released from a height <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math> above the ground. Block <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> of mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> falls straight down, and Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> slides down the incline as shown in the figure. There is negligible friction between Block <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> and the incline. After the blocks have fallen a vertical distance <math alttext="h" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>h</mi></math>, which of the following is true about the final speeds <math alttext="v sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="v sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and final mechanical energies <math alttext="E sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="E sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> of Blocks <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, respectively?
content.question: Final velocitiesFinal energiesA<math alttext="v sub A equals v sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math><math alttext="E sub A is greater than E sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>B</mi></msub></mstyle></math>B<math alttext="v sub A equals v sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math><math alttext="E sub A is less than E sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>C<math alttext="v sub A is greater than v sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math><math alttext="E sub A equals E sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>D<math alttext="v sub A is less than v sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math><math alttext="E sub A equals E sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
